qas.question: In what systems is the political party allowed to legally hold effective power?
What are North Korea and China examples of?

answers.text: positions within the party may in fact be more important than positions within the government

qas.question: What is the one-party system often compared with?
When was Nazi Germany in a one-party system?
What kind of leadership must the dominant party accept in China?
During what years did North Korea move to a one party system?
What are minor parties often compared to due to their influence?
What are minor parties usually identical to?
In what country were minor party positions more important?

context: In <a0_0>one-party systems<a0_0/>, one political party is legally allowed to hold effective power. Although <b4_0>minor parties<b4_0/> may sometimes be allowed, they are legally required to accept the leadership of the dominant party. This party may not always be identical to <b7_0>the government<b7_0/>, although sometimes <a1_0>positions within the party may in fact be more important than positions within the government<a1_0/>. North Korea and <b8_0>China<b8_0/> are examples; others can be found in Fascist states, such as Nazi Germany <b5_0>between <a3_0>1934 and 1945<b5_0/><a3_0/>. The one-party system is thus usually equated with <a2_0><b6_0>dictatorships and tyranny<b6_0/><a2_0/>.
